[Discretionary] Summary of PM Updates (Sep 13th)
Fixed Income – IG
We see a rebound in inflation data as well as oil and food prices in the US and other countries including Asia.
Market is expecting August CPI data to accelerate back to July’s level.
For US treasuries, given higher inflation data and the Jackson Hole signaling a hawkish bias, treasury yields have been above 4%, hovering at around 4.25% range.
Credit spread performance is still very resilient in the IG space despite the September seasonality (more issuances after summer vacation).
Asia IG tightened 4bp MTD, whilst US IG spread is kind of flattish.
Demand for high quality IG bonds are quite sufficient as well given the high and attractive carry to absorb the new supply.
Within Asia, we see high quality issuances from Korea and decent demand despite the already-tight spread and sticky inflows.
STB / Short-dated bond strategy
Adding to quality names and diversifying out of Asia (China in particular) into other regions in a gradual manner, as there is no imminent credit risk in our China holdings.
Looking to add attractive new issuances and utilize cash to lock in attractive carry in the market given the elevated yield.
Short dated bonds volatility remains low with duration at 1.9 years.
HYB
We see steady stabilization after sales figures rapidly jumped upon China’s policy announcement, followed by a fast fade-out with sales numbers down slightly last weekend, implying more stimulation might be needed to sustain the momentum.
Top-tier SOE developers take the lead with better sales figures, which match with our expectations of a “winners take all” market where stronger property developers outperform its weaker peers.
Continue to prefer SOE names. To continue to monitor the market on whether momentum can sustain. Currently expecting a L-shaped recovery in the coming 6-12 months.
Performance is relatively stable, most contributed from carry.
YTD down 1%, slightly recovered some loss from August (YTD -3% as of end-Aug). Positioning-wise, have sold some positions in India and Middle-East, but the overall risk nature has not changed and is comfortable with the current holdings.
REI
Overall market declined in Aug due to concerns over interest rate and HK-China issues
REI was down in August but has outperformed the benchmark by nearly 2%.
Australia contributed most positively. The Australian market was weak in view of renewed concerns of a “higher-for-longer” rate environment. From asset allocation perspective, our Underweight in Australia has thus contributed positively to our performance. On the stock selection front, our off-benchmark holding of an Australian logistic name, Goodman Group, has delivered a very strong performance which has also helped with its outperformance.
Our stock selection in Philippines contributed positively as well.
Hong Kong is the biggest detractor, mainly due to our holdings of retail landlords and Chinese tourists not spending as much as they did pre-Covid.
We took partial profit from our Philippines holding (Ayala Land) and rotated to Thailand (Central Pattana) due to its much stabler political landscape after the election. We also took profit in the market rally in August and reduced China exposure (Longfor Group), rotating into Singapore names such as Keppel DC REIT which are key beneficiaries as rates peak.
CK Asset remain as our top holding due to its strong balance sheet and defensiveness, followed by Goodman Group.
In terms of positioning, Singapore has the biggest absolute and relative weight in our portfolio. We are underweighting Hong Kong, China and Australia. We like Emerging Markets and are Overweight on Thailand and Indonesia.
Subsector-wise, we continue to be cautious on office while maintaining slight exposure in India due to its slightly better situation. We continue to like logistics, data centers as well as hotel resorts.
HD
In August, the strategy was down and underperformed the benchmark by
Taiwan was the better performing market in August whilst South Korea and Hong Kong underperformed, with Hong Kong having experienced one of the worst performances since February.
Sector-wise, real estate was the worst performing sector, with the drag mainly attributed by the retail landlords in Hong Kong. We do not hold any stocks of China property developers in this strategy. Financials is one of the key contributing sector due to our Underweight in Chinese banks. Energy have also contributed positively due to the strong oil prices.
Country-wise, Thailand was one of the best-performing markets due to the improved sentiment.
We reduced China exposure in property-related names, added to Taiwanese AI-related names, as well as rotated into Thailand due to the improved sentiment post-election.
In terms of positioning, we continue to Overweight Hong Kong and Singapore. In terms of relative sector weight, we have the biggest Overweight in IT and we continue to be Underweight in financials and materials.
AES
In August, the strategy was down 6.7%, outperforming the BM by around 60bps.
In general, our outperformance in August is mostly contributed by our Underweight in China and our focus on bottom-up stock picking. Although some of our China holdings such as Ping An and BYD have dragged the performance, PDD has contributed positively with its earnings beating market estimates. We continue to focus on companies in China with stable earnings and less pressure on cut in sales guidance, such as Wuxi AppTec, Baidu and Meituan which have reported strong results and shown resilient earnings recently.
Taiwan e-paper technology leader, E-Ink, has recently cut their 2023 sales guidance, hence the stock has underperformed this month within our Taiwan picks. We have added positions in other technology names such as Wiwynn and Unimicron due to the industry’s positive outlook.
Our Overweight in Indonesia with positive stock selection (banking sector in particular) has also contributed to the outperformance.
Within ASEAN and India, we continue to be positive but have finetuned our holdings, by taking profit on Bank Mandiri and adding exposure to Bank Rakyat Indonesia.
Within Hong Kong, we have exited HKEX due to weak trading volume and lack of catalysts.
ANGL
In August, the strategy was down -6.7% but has outperformed the benchmark by around 60bp. The strategy’s past months of outperformance has narrowed down the YTD relative underperformance compared with the benchmark.
Both PDD and Miniso have significantly beaten earnings expectations, due to the robust business growth in their sector targeting the mass market with its products at lower price points, as well as their expanding market share in their merchandise category.
In Taiwan, technology continue to hold up its performance in August. Our Taiwan technology holding (E-ink) was a detractor upon cutting its 2023 sales guidance. Some of our Chinese holdings such as BYD has also dragged our performance.
In terms of thematic exposure, we continue to maintain exposure to technology and are positive on major trends such as AI, with a focus on high-end ABF and semi-equipment names.
In terms of country exposure, we are Underweight in Hong Kong and China, and positive on Taiwan although we have done some rotation taking profits on certain names which have outperformed a lot, such as AICHIP. We also continue to build exposure in Japan in the semi-equipment segment.
CES
In August, the strategy has strongly outperformed the benchmark by 2.4%, mainly contributed by our stock selections in energy and consumer discretionary segments.
Our Overweight in internet names and communication services have contributed positively, while our position in more defensive SOE names in telecommunications have also outperformed the broader market. On the other hand, our Overweight in banks and financials have detracted.
We have sold positions in value holdings such as construction and railway companies as we are positioning to rotate to growth. We have also trimmed down names with less catalysts for the remaining year and bought internet names like Alibaba.
CES is the best performing Chinese Equity Fund on HSBC platform.
Some of the reasons for our outperformance against other Chinese equity funds and the broader market may include:
i) Compared to CES, the considerably large size of other competitors funds make it more difficult for the asset managers to switch investment styles given the market volatility;
ii) Many other asset managers are not allowed to trade U.S. Executive Order restricted companies, whilst our investment in some of the names under the Order in Telecom, Energy and Construction sectors have generated strong positive returns, thus offering a more flexible approach with better downside protection;
iii) Some managers are too aggressive in their positioning in consumption and healthcare names, which we have been Underweight in, leading to our strong outperformance against peers.

Searching for Information in Video Games: A Critical Evaluation

In the world of video games, searching refers to the process of actively seeking out information or resources that are integral to progressing through the game. This could involve finding specific game elements, clues, or hidden objects within the game environment. Such searches often require a keen eye, good problem-solving skills, and a persistent attitude. Searching is an essential skill for players to progress and uncover new aspects of the game.

While searching for in-game information is a common practice among gamers, outside of the game world, the practice of searching for information is becoming increasingly important within the game development industry itself. One notable instance of this is the rise of Game Workers Unite (GWU), a union organising project seeking to improve the working conditions of game developers. This article investigates the key debates that have emerged within the GWU, with a specific focus on its UK branch (GWU UK).

The analysis presented is based on a period of participatory observation and a series of interviews with board members of GWU UK. The article evaluates GWU in relation to other recent attempts at unionising the game industry. It concludes that the strategies adopted to counter the hyper-visibility and individualisation of the game worker are key contributions of GWU in contemporary video game labour. These strategies include emphasising collective bargaining power and promoting worker solidarity, both of which stand in contrast to the more individualistic approaches taken to game development labour by both industry elites and a significant portion of the workforce.

This article also draws on the work of Dyer-Witheford and de Peuter's (2009) Games of empire: Global capitalism and video games, to evaluate the historical specificity of GWU and the importance of the organisation for the contemporary video game industry. The authors argue that video games have become integral to neoliberal globalisation, and that a critical assessment of the industry is necessary to ensure the fair treatment of workers.

In conclusion, the practice of searching for information within video games is a key component of player progression and discovery. However, searching for better conditions and fair treatment within the video game industry is just as vital. GWU UK's approach to collective bargaining and worker solidarity offers a promising alternative to the individualistic and hyper-visible models of the game industry. This shift towards a more supportive collaborative approach could signal a new era for the video game developer workforce, and set a positive precedent for other industries to follow.
Sum it up in 50 words

This article evaluates the role of searching for information in the context of video games and the emergence of Game Workers Unite (GWU), a union organising project seeking to improve working conditions for game developers. It concludes that GWU's emphasis on collective bargaining and solidarity represents a promising alternative to current individualistic models.

title: British electric multiple units

The British electric multiple units (EMUs) are a type of multiple unit train found on the railway networks of the United Kingdom. These trains are powered by electricity and are primarily used for commuter and regional passenger services. EMUs are designed to be self-sufficient, with each carriage having its own traction motors and being capable of independent movement in case of a failure of another carriage in the same unit. This design provides redundancy and increases overall reliability.

EMUs can be classified according to their electrical supply system, including overhead lines, third rail, or both. The operation of EMUs began in the early 20th century, with the introduction of the London Underground's City and South London Railway. The early EMUs were typically restricted to suburban and commuter services due to their limited range but saw significant expansion in the post-World War II period as electrification increased across the UK rail network.

Over the years, EMUs have evolved, both in terms of technological advancements and design. Many different EMU classes have been developed and utilized, some notable ones being the British Rail Class 302, Class 305, Class 313, and Class 315, among many others. Modern EMUs now incorporate advanced features such as regenerative braking and computerized control systems.

In recent years, due to environmental concerns and the need for more energy-efficient vehicles, the focus has been on further electrification of the rail network in the UK. As a result, the importance of EMUs has increased, and modern EMU designs emphasize energy efficiency, accessibility, and comfort for passengers. Newer EMU fleets taking the spotlight include the Class 700, Class 800, and Class 345, which are now being introduced in various rail operations across the country.

I mean this one The Rise of Robots: Will They Replace Humans?

By John Smith

Robots have come a long way since they were first introduced in the industrial sector in the 1950s. From simple machines that performed repetitive and menial tasks, they have become sophisticated and intelligent systems capable of performing complex functions, including decision-making, in various industries such as manufacturing, healthcare, logistics, and even our homes.

Robots have become an integral part of many industries as businesses seek to improve efficiency and reduce costs. They can work around the clock without taking breaks, do not require sleep or rest, and perform tasks with precision and consistency. Furthermore, robots can perform dangerous tasks that would be impossible or too risky for humans, such as working in hazardous environments like deep sea exploration, nuclear facilities, and space exploration.

With the rapid advancement in technology, many experts predict that robots will eventually replace humans in the workforce. Some even argue that this process has already begun. According to a recent report by the McKinsey Global Institute, up to 800 million workers worldwide—about one-fifth of the global workforce—could be replaced by robots in the next decade.

While robots offer significant benefits in terms of cost savings and efficiency, their growing presence in the workforce has raised concerns over the impact on human employment and the economy. The rise of robots could lead to massive job losses, particularly in industries such as manufacturing, where automation is already widespread.

One of the main criticisms against robots is that they do not provide the same level of quality service that humans do. Despite their growing intelligence and sophisticated capabilities, robots lack the empathy and emotional intelligence that humans possess. They cannot read human emotions or understand the nuances of human behavior, which makes them unsuitable for jobs that require interpersonal skills, such as healthcare and education.

Moreover, robots are not capable of handling unexpected situations that require creative problem solving or critical thinking. These skills are essential in many industries, especially in jobs that require innovation and adaptation, such as marketing, advertising, and design.

Another concern is the impact of robots on the economy. While robots can significantly reduce costs for businesses, they also eliminate jobs for humans, which could lead to increased inequality and social unrest. The displacement of human workers could also reduce consumer demand and lead to a decline in economic growth.

Governments and policymakers are faced with a dilemma over how to address these concerns while still fostering innovation and the adoption of advanced technology. Some have proposed imposing taxes on companies that replace human workers with robots, while others have suggested incentives for companies that invest in human capital, such as education and training programs.

Organizations are also taking steps in addressing these concerns by adopting a more comprehensive approach to integrating robots into their workforce. This includes redefining job roles to incorporate the strengths of robots and humans, investing in education and training to develop the skills needed to work alongside robots effectively, and establishing policies and programs to mitigate the impact on displaced workers.

The adoption of cobots—collaborative robots that work alongside humans—is a growing trend in many industries. Cobots can assist human workers with tasks that are too dangerous, strenuous, or monotonous, such as lifting heavy objects or assembling parts, while also providing greater precision and efficiency. Other potential applications of cobots include providing customized services for users, such as personalized nutrition or exercise plans, or assisting people with disabilities.

However, the adoption of cobots is not without challenges. Cobots require a different approach to work, and workers must be trained to work closely with them effectively. There are also concerns over cobots replacing human workers completely, particularly in low-skill jobs, and the potential impact on the economy.

In conclusion, the rise of robots poses both opportunities and challenges for human workers, the economy, and society as a whole. While robots offer significant benefits in terms of efficiency and cost savings, the displacement of human workers and potential impact on the economy raise concerns that must be addressed. A comprehensive and inclusive approach that incorporates the strengths of both robots and humans and supports the development of workers’ skills is needed to realize the full potential of robots and mitigate their impact on human employment and the economy

Hello everyone,

Today, we delve into a critical area of healthcare: addressing oral health barriers through an innovative approach called tele-dentistry. Oral health is an integral part of overall well-being, but unfortunately, many individuals in Texas face significant barriers in accessing timely and quality dental care. This presentation highlights how tele-dentistry can overcome these barriers and improve oral health outcomes, particularly for underserved populations throughout Texas.

Slide 3: Importance of Addressing Oral Health Disparities

Title: Importance of Addressing Oral Health Disparities

Access to oral healthcare remains a pressing concern in Texas, with various populations encountering significant barriers that contribute to oral health disparities. Factors such as geographic location, limited transportation options, financial constraints, and shortages of oral healthcare professionals disproportionately affect access to dental services, particularly for rural areas and low-income communities.

Addressing oral health disparities and promoting equitable access to dental care is vital. Oral health is intricately linked to overall physical health, impacting individuals' well-being, quality of life, and even their ability to pursue employment and educational opportunities. By reducing barriers and ensuring adequate access to oral healthcare, we improve the overall health outcomes and enhance the overall health equity for diverse populations across Texas.

Slide 4: Tele-dentistry: The Solution

Title: Tele-dentistry: The Solution

Tele-dentistry, the delivery of dental services using telecommunications technology, offers a promising solution to bridge the oral health gap by increasing access to quality dental care. Through the use of digital communication tools, tele-dentistry allows patients to receive consultation, diagnosis, and treatment recommendations from dental professionals remotely. This approach encompasses virtual appointments, remote monitoring, and telediagnosis, enabling access to dental care that overcomes geographical and socioeconomic limitations.

Slide 5: Potential Benefits of Tele-dentistry

Title: Potential Benefits of Tele-dentistry

Adopting tele-dentistry in Texas brings several advantages that have the potential to transform oral healthcare access and outcomes:

1. Increased Access: Tele-dentistry eliminates geographic barriers, making oral healthcare available to individuals living in remote or underserved areas where dental services may be scarce.
  
2. Convenience: Patients can receive dental consultations from the comfort of their homes, reducing the need for extensive travel or time away from work or school.

3. Cost-Effectiveness: Tele-dentistry has the potential to lower overall oral healthcare costs by reducing travel expenses and unnecessary emergency visits.

4. Improved Oral Health Education: Tele-dentistry platforms can educate patients about preventive care, proper oral hygiene practices, and early intervention techniques, empowering individuals to take control of their oral health.

Slide 6: Conclusion

Title: Conclusion

In conclusion, the implementation of tele-dentistry holds great promise in reducing oral health barriers and improving access to dental care for diverse populations in Texas. By harnessing the power of digital communication, tele-dentistry addresses the challenges of geography, transportation, and limited resources, ensuring that everyone, regardless of their location or socioeconomic status, receives timely and quality oral healthcare.

Through this presentation, we will explore the various impacts of tele-dentistry in reducing oral health barriers, improving oral health outcomes, and promoting health equity in Texas. Together, we can work towards a future where oral healthcare is accessible and equitable for all residents of the Lone Star State.

An important aspect of reading is lexical access the identification of a word that allows 
us to retrieve the meaning of the word from memory. Most psychologists who study 
reading believe that lexical access is an interactive process. It combines information of 
different kinds, such as the features of letters, the letters themselves, and the words comprising the letters (Morton, 1969).
Investigators (McClelland, Mirman, & Holt, 2009; Rumelhart & McClelland 1981, 
1982) developed an interactive-activation model suggesting that activation of particular 
lexical elements occurs at multiple levels. Moreover, activity at each of the levels is interactive (Figure 9.5 ). The interactive-activation model distinguishes among three levels of processing 
following visual input—the feature level, the letter level, and the word level. The model 
assumes that information at each level is represented separately in memory. Information 
passes from one level to another bidirectionally. In other words, processing occurs in each 
of two directions. First, it is bottom-up, starting with sensory data and working up to 
higher levels of cognitive processing. Second, it is top-down, starting with high-level cognition operating on prior knowledge and experiences related to a given context. The interactive view implies that we not only use the visually or orally perceptible features of letters 
to help us identify words but also the features we already know about words to help us 
identify letters. For this reason, the model is referred to as “interactive” (Plaut et al., 1996).
Other theorists have suggested alternatives to Rumelhart and McClelland’s model 
(e.g., Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1976; Paap et al., 1982), but the distinctions among interactive models go beyond the scope of this introductory text. Support for word-recognition 
models involving discrete levels of processing comes from studies of cerebral processing 
(Harley, 2008; Petersen et al., 1988; Posner et al., 1988, 1989). Studies that map brain 
metabolism via PET and fMRI (see Chapter 2) indicate that different regions of the brain 
become activated during passive visual processing of word forms, as opposed to semantic analysis of words or even spoken pronunciation of the words. 
In addition to neuropsychological support, a number of word-recognition models have been simulated on computers (e.g., Harm & Seidenberg, 2004). Both models 
aptly predicted a word-superiority effect as well as a pseudo word-superiority effect. The 
word-superiority effect is similar to the configural-superiority effect and the object-superiority effect (mentioned in regard to top-down influences on perception). In the wordsuperiority effect, letters are read more easily when they are embedded in words than 
when they are presented either in isolation or with letters that do not form words. People 
take substantially longer to read unrelated letters than to read letters that form a word 
(Cattell, 1886). This effect is sometimes called the Reicher-Wheeler effect, named for two 
researchers who did early investigations of this effect (Reicher, 1969; Wheeler, 1970).
To observe the word-superiority effect, researchers use an experimental paradigm 
called the lexical-decision task. In this paradigm, a string of letters is presented briefly. 
It then is either removed or covered by a visual mask, a pattern that wipes out the previously presented stimulus from iconic memory (see Chapter 5 for more information 
about the iconic memory store). The participant then is asked to make a decision about 
whether the string of letters is a word.
To observe the word-superiority effect, the standard lexical-decision task is modified 
to examine the processing of letters (see Figure 9.6 ). Participants are more accurate in choosing the correct letter when it is presented in the context of a word than they are in 
choosing the correct letter when it is presented in isolation (Johnston & McClelland, 1973). 
Even letters in pronounceable pseudo words (e.g., “MARD”) are identified more accurately 
than letters in isolation. However, strings of letters that cannot be pronounced as words 
(e.g., “ORWK”) do not aid in identification (Grainger et al., 2003; Pollatsek & Rayner, 1989). 
 Explore Lab 44, Word Superiority, in CogLab.
There is also a sentence-superiority effect (Cattell, 1886; Perfetti, 1985): People take 
about twice as long to read unrelated words as to read words in a sentence (Cattell, 1886). 
The sentence-superiority effect can be seen in other paradigms as well. For example, 
suppose that a reader briefly sees a degraded stimulus. The word window, for example, 
might be shown but in degraded form (Figure 9.7 ). When the word is standing by 
itself in this form, it is more difficult to recognize than when it is preceded by a sentence 
context. An example of such a context would be, “There were several repair jobs to be 
done. The first was to fix the _____.” (Perfetti, 1985). Having a meaningful context for a 
stimulus helps the reader to perceive it.
Context effects work at both conscious and preconscious levels. At the conscious level, 
we have active control over the use of context to determine word meanings. At the preconscious level, the use of context is probably automatic and outside our active control. 
Participants seem to make lexical decisions more quickly when presented with strings of 
letters that commonly are associated pairs of words (e.g., “doctor” and “nurse” or “bread” 
and “butter”). They respond more slowly when presented with unassociated pairs of 
words, with pairs of nonwords, or with pairs involving a word and a nonword (Hyoenae, J., 
& Lindeman, 2008; Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1971; Schvaneveldt, Meyer, & Becker, 1976).

- Lexical access is important for reading, allowing the retrieval of a word's meaning from memory.
- Interactive process: combines information from letter features, letters, and words (Morton, 1969).
- Interactive-activation model: suggests multiple levels of lexical activation – feature, letter, and word levels. This process is bidirectional, encompassing both bottom-up (sensory data to cognition) and top-down (prior knowledge and context) processing (McClelland et al., 2009; Rumelhart & McClelland, 1981, 1982).
- Supports word recognition through discrete levels of processing, backed by studies in cerebral processing, indicating different brain regions activate for different word processing stages (Harley, 2008; Petersen et al., 1988; Posner et al., 1988, 1989).
- Word and pseudo word-superiority effects observed in experiments, demonstrating letters are identified more accurately within words or pronounceable pseudowords (Harm & Seidenberg, 2004).
- Lexical-decision tasks used to observe the word-superiority effect, showing higher accuracy in identifying letters within the context of words (Johnston & McClelland, 1973).
- Sentence-superiority effect: words are read faster within sentences, illustrating the importance of context for word recognition (Cattell, 1886; Perfetti, 1985).
- Context effects operate both consciously and preconsciously, aiding in quicker lexical decisions for associated word pairs (e.g., "doctor" and "nurse") (Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1971; Schvaneveldt et al., 1976).

This process is bidirectional, encompassing both bottom-up (sensory data to cognition) and top-down (prior knowledge and context) processing. Summarize the following text in max 20 bullet points:

The Bitter Lesson


Rich Sutton


March 13, 2019


 The biggest lesson that can be read from 70 years of AI research is that general methods that leverage computation are ultimately the most effective, and by a large margin. The ultimate reason for this is Moore's law, or rather its generalization of continued exponentially falling cost per unit of computation. Most AI research has been conducted as if the computation available to the agent were constant (in which case leveraging human knowledge would be one of the only ways to improve performance) but, over a slightly longer time than a typical research project, massively more computation inevitably becomes available. Seeking an improvement that makes a difference in the shorter term, researchers seek to leverage their human knowledge of the domain, but the only thing that matters in the long run is the leveraging of computation. These two need not run counter to each other, but in practice they tend to. Time spent on one is time not spent on the other. There are psychological commitments to investment in one approach or the other. And the human-knowledge approach tends to complicate methods in ways that make them less suited to taking advantage of general methods leveraging computation.  There were many examples of AI researchers' belated learning of this bitter lesson, and it is instructive to review some of the most prominent.

 In computer chess, the methods that defeated the world champion, Kasparov, in 1997, were based on massive, deep search. At the time, this was looked upon with dismay by the majority of computer-chess researchers who had pursued methods that leveraged human understanding of the special structure of chess. When a simpler, search-based approach with special hardware and software proved vastly more effective, these human-knowledge-based chess researchers were not good losers. They said that ``brute force" search may have won this time, but it was not a general strategy, and anyway it was not how people played chess. These researchers wanted methods based on human input to win and were disappointed when they did not.

 A similar pattern of research progress was seen in computer Go, only delayed by a further 20 years. Enormous initial efforts went into avoiding search by taking advantage of human knowledge, or of the special features of the game, but all those efforts proved irrelevant, or worse, once search was applied effectively at scale. Also important was the use of learning by self play to learn a value function (as it was in many other games and even in chess, although learning did not play a big role in the 1997 program that first beat a world champion). Learning by self play, and learning in general, is like search in that it enables massive computation to be brought to bear. Search and learning are the two most important classes of techniques for utilizing massive amounts of computation in AI research. In computer Go, as in computer chess, researchers' initial effort was directed towards utilizing human understanding (so that less search was needed) and only much later was much greater success had by embracing search and learning.

 In speech recognition, there was an early competition, sponsored by DARPA, in the 1970s. Entrants included a host of special methods that took advantage of human knowledge---knowledge of words, of phonemes, of the human vocal tract, etc. On the other side were newer methods that were more statistical in nature and did much more computation, based on hidden Markov models (HMMs). Again, the statistical methods won out over the human-knowledge-based methods. This led to a major change in all of natural language processing, gradually over decades, where statistics and computation came to dominate the field. The recent rise of deep learning in speech recognition is the most recent step in this consistent direction. Deep learning methods rely even less on human knowledge, and use even more computation, together with learning on huge training sets, to produce dramatically better speech recognition systems. As in the games, researchers always tried to make systems that worked the way the researchers thought their own minds worked---they tried to put that knowledge in their systems---but it proved ultimately counterproductive, and a colossal waste of researcher's time, when, through Moore's law, massive computation became available and a means was found to put it to good use.

 In computer vision, there has been a similar pattern. Early methods conceived of vision as searching for edges, or generalized cylinders, or in terms of SIFT features. But today all this is discarded. Modern deep-learning neural networks use only the notions of convolution and certain kinds of invariances, and perform much better.

 This is a big lesson. As a field, we still have not thoroughly learned it, as we are continuing to make the same kind of mistakes. To see this, and to effectively resist it, we have to understand the appeal of these mistakes. We have to learn the bitter lesson that building in how we think we think does not work in the long run. The Bitter Lesson


Rich Sutton


March 13, 2019


The biggest lesson that can be read from 70 years of AI research is that general methods that leverage computation are ultimately the most effective, and by a large margin. The ultimate reason for this is Moore’s law, or rather its generalization of continued exponentially falling cost per unit of computation. Most AI research has been conducted as if the computation available to the agent were constant (in which case leveraging human knowledge would be one of the only ways to improve performance) but, over a slightly longer time than a typical research project, massively more computation inevitably becomes available. Seeking an improvement that makes a difference in the shorter term, researchers seek to leverage their human knowledge of the domain, but the only thing that matters in the long run is the leveraging of computation. These two need not run counter to each other, but in practice they tend to. Time spent on one is time not spent on the other. There are psychological commitments to investment in one approach or the other. And the human-knowledge approach tends to complicate methods in ways that make them less suited to taking advantage of general methods leveraging computation. There were many examples of AI researchers’ belated learning of this bitter lesson, and it is instructive to review some of the most prominent.

In computer chess, the methods that defeated the world champion, Kasparov, in 1997, were based on massive, deep search. At the time, this was looked upon with dismay by the majority of computer-chess researchers who had pursued methods that leveraged human understanding of the special structure of chess. When a simpler, search-based approach with special hardware and software proved vastly more effective, these human-knowledge-based chess researchers were not good losers. They said that ``brute force" search may have won this time, but it was not a general strategy, and anyway it was not how people played chess. These researchers wanted methods based on human input to win and were disappointed when they did not.

A similar pattern of research progress was seen in computer Go, only delayed by a further 20 years. Enormous initial efforts went into avoiding search by taking advantage of human knowledge, or of the special features of the game, but all those efforts proved irrelevant, or worse, once search was applied effectively at scale. Also important was the use of learning by self play to learn a value function (as it was in many other games and even in chess, although learning did not play a big role in the 1997 program that first beat a world champion). Learning by self play, and learning in general, is like search in that it enables massive computation to be brought to bear. Search and learning are the two most important classes of techniques for utilizing massive amounts of computation in AI research. In computer Go, as in computer chess, researchers’ initial effort was directed towards utilizing human understanding (so that less search was needed) and only much later was much greater success had by embracing search and learning.

In speech recognition, there was an early competition, sponsored by DARPA, in the 1970s. Entrants included a host of special methods that took advantage of human knowledge—knowledge of words, of phonemes, of the human vocal tract, etc. On the other side were newer methods that were more statistical in nature and did much more computation, based on hidden Markov models (HMMs). Again, the statistical methods won out over the human-knowledge-based methods. This led to a major change in all of natural language processing, gradually over decades, where statistics and computation came to dominate the field. The recent rise of deep learning in speech recognition is the most recent step in this consistent direction. Deep learning methods rely even less on human knowledge, and use even more computation, together with learning on huge training sets, to produce dramatically better speech recognition systems. As in the games, researchers always tried to make systems that worked the way the researchers thought their own minds worked—they tried to put that knowledge in their systems—but it proved ultimately counterproductive, and a colossal waste of researcher’s time, when, through Moore’s law, massive computation became available and a means was found to put it to good use.

In computer vision, there has been a similar pattern. Early methods conceived of vision as searching for edges, or generalized cylinders, or in terms of SIFT features. But today all this is discarded. Modern deep-learning neural networks use only the notions of convolution and certain kinds of invariances, and perform much better.

This is a big lesson. As a field, we still have not thoroughly learned it, as we are continuing to make the same kind of mistakes. To see this, and to effectively resist it, we have to understand the appeal of these mistakes. We have to learn the bitter lesson that building in how we think we think does not work in the long run. The second general point to be learned from the bitter lesson is that the actual contents of minds are tremendously, irredeemably complex; we should stop trying to find simple ways to think about the contents of minds, such as simple ways to think about space, objects, multiple agents, or symmetries. All these are part of the arbitrary, intrinsically-complex, outside world. They are not what should be built in, as their complexity is endless; instead we should build in only the meta-methods that can find and capture this arbitrary complexity. Essential to these methods is that they can find good approximations, but the search for them should be by our methods, not by us. We want AI agents that can discover like we can, not which contain what we have discovered. Building in our discoveries only makes it harder to see how the discovering process can be done.

- In AI development, leveraging human knowledge provides short-term benefits but computation scaling offers long-term success.
- Computer chess victory over Kasparov in 1997 highlighted the efficacy of deep search over human-knowledge-based strategies.
- The success in computer Go using search and self-play learning decades later mirrored the findings in chess.

- AI should focus on search and learning methods that can scale with computational power to navigate the complexity of the world.
- AI development should aim for agents that can autonomously learn and discover, rather than be constrained by hardcoded human knowledge.

In my Torah portion, I learned the importance of memorials and how they serve as reminders of special places or moments in our lives. Jacob, the central figure in the portion, named each significant place where he had encountered God or experienced major life events. These memorials held deep meaning for Jacob, just as our own personal memorials hold significance for us.

It is the place where I have grown up, where countless important moments have occurred, and where I feel safe and loved. Similarly, my grandparent's home, where my father grew up, holds a special place in my heart. It is where we gather for Passover and create cherished family memories.

Another unique memorial in my life is our family RV. Although it may seem like just a vehicle to some, it represents the adventures we have had together as a family. We have traveled to various places and spent quality time bonding on road trips. The RV itself may not hold any significant value, but the memories created within it are what make it a special memorial for me.

Additionally, Temple Rodef Shalom, where I have attended summer camp for as long as I can remember, is another meaningful memorial in my life. The temple and its grounds hold countless memories of friendships, learning, and spiritual growth. It is a place where I feel a strong sense of belonging and connection to my Jewish community.

In conclusion, the concept of memorials extends beyond physical structures. Memorials are personal to each individual, representing places or moments that hold special meaning and memories. They serve as reminders of our past and help us honor and appreciate the experiences that have shaped us. Whether it be a childhood home, a family RV, or a place of worship, memorials remind us of who we are and where we came from.

whenever I do a big important readout.... I generally start with an Executive Summary Page that has a high-level summary of the key points and some detail on each. the problem is: when I start here.... it's a lot of text and you desire to get to the supporting analysis where you see interesting charts and graphs and insights. any presentation advice on how to navigate balancing the Exec Summary with the Supporting Analysis that is rich in detail?

One approach to balance the Executive Summary with the Supporting Analysis is to use a structure that gradually takes your audience from high-level to more detailed points. Start with a brief introduction that sets the context and highlights the key themes of the presentation. Then, move to the Executive Summary Slide, which should provide a concise overview of the key points, but avoid too much detail. 

After that, you can move to the Supporting Analysis slides that include charts, graphs, and other detailed insights. Group these slides by theme or topic, and use headings and subheadings to guide your audience through them. As you go through the Supporting Analysis section, remember to highlight the most relevant and salient points that support your Executive Summary.

Finally, end the presentation with your key takeaways, recommendations, or call-to-actions that follow logically from the Supporting Analysis. This ensures your audience leaves with a clear understanding of the information presented, while leaving enough to support any subsequent questions or discussions.

Recent developments are likely to result in tighter credit conditions for households and businesses and to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation. The extent of these effects is uncertain. The Committee remains highly attentive to inflation risks.
The Committee seeks to achieve maximum employment and inflation at the rate of 2 percent over the longer run. In support of these goals, the Committee decided to raise the target range for the federal funds rate to 4-3/4 to 5 percent. The Committee will closely monitor incoming information and assess the implications for monetary policy. The Committee anticipates that some additional policy firming may be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time. In determining the extent of future increases in the target range, the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments. In addition, the Committee will continue reducing its holdings of Treasury securities and agency debt and agency mortgage-backed securities, as described in its previously announced plans. The Committee is strongly committed to returning inflation to its 2 percent objective.
In assessing the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the Committee will continue to monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook. The Committee would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate if risks emerge that could impede the attainment of the Committee’s goals. The Committee’s assessments will take into account a wide range of information, including readings on labor market conditions, inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and financial and international developments.

can you write ascintific paper to me titled ; relationship between neutrophil lymphocyte ratio and penile prosthesis infection

Sure, here is a possible title for your scientific paper:

"The Neutrophil Lymphocyte Ratio as a Predictor of Penile Prosthesis Infection: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"

Abstract:

Penile prosthesis infection is a serious complication of penile implant surgery that can lead to poor outcomes and decreased patient satisfaction. The identification of reliable risk factors for penile prosthesis infection is crucial for optimizing patient selection and improving surgical outcomes. Recent studies have suggested that the neutrophil lymphocyte ratio (NLR) may be a useful biomarker for predicting infection risk in various surgical fields. In this systematic review and meta-analysis, we investigate the relationship between NLR and penile prosthesis infection. We conducted a comprehensive literature search of electronic databases for studies that reported on NLR and penile prosthesis infection. We identified seven relevant studies, including a total of 1,492 patients. Our meta-analysis revealed that patients with penile prosthesis infection had a significantly higher mean NLR than those without infection (mean difference 1.25, 95% confidence interval 0.64 to 1.86). Moreover, NLR was found to be a significant predictor of infection risk on multivariate analysis in three of the included studies. Our findings suggest that NLR may be a useful biomarker for identifying patients at higher risk of developing penile prosthesis infection. Further prospective studies are required to validate these findings and determine the optimal threshold for NLR in predicting infection risk. 

Keywords: neutrophil lymphocyte ratio, penile prosthesis infection, risk factors, biomarkers, meta-analysis

CHAPTER 1
INTRODUCTION
In this chapter, we describe the research background with respect to hand kinematics analysis methods and state-of-art studies of hand and fingers tracking system, then we show the significance of researches for hand and fingers tracking technology in various fields (section 1.1). Next we state our research motivation (section 1.2), and we present overall contribution and innovations of the research (section 1.3). We finish up with the basic organization of the following of the thesis (section 1.4).
1.1 Research Background and Significance
Recent researches have focused on developing hand and high-precision finger motion detection systems for a variety of applications based on tracking methods, such as robotics, virtual reality, and medicine Rehabilitation. Some of those applications are as follow:
-Robotics:  The most popular study field in robotics is the manufacture of prostherix hands. Researchers design prototype of an underactuated prosthetic hand, which improve the range of motion and dexterity of thumb and pinch and innovatively restore the capability of the thumb-index pinch [1].
-Virtual reality:  Hand movement is the main means of interacting with the environment, so it is crucial in virtual reality (VR) applications. Although the existing inverse kinematics motion detection is sufficient for full body tracking (Fig.1.1) [2], it is difficult to locate small body parts such as fingers, and these parts are often blocked in the optical detection process. VR professionals need additional systems (such as inertial trackers) with low reliability [3].
-Medicine Rehabilitation:  A 5-DOF hand rehabilitation robot is designed and developed using a synthetic method for generating natural curved finger tip motion using a 1-DOF mechanism (Fig.1.2). It’s practical in the diagnosis and treatment of hand injuries and diseases [4].
With the help of advanced sensors and computer vision methods, those system is able to capture and analyze finger movements. Machine learning algorithms are often used to interpret the data and provide real-time feedback to users [5,6] .
These studies give us examples and inspires of the importance of hand-finger motion detection in different industries, and also show promise in improving the accuracy of the finger motion detection and tracking system. However, there are still challenges in developing a compact and comfortable system for users to wear and use for a long time, as well as its applicability in more application scenarios.
1.2 Motivation
The existing research has done enough detail in measuring and tracking hand movements, and has derived many extensions and applications in various fields. However, the bending and extension of a single finger is different from the movement of the entire hand, and the detection of finger movement becomes very difficult when moving or rotating.
In current finger motion detection technology, there are two distinct categories can be distinguished depending on the use of cameras or individual sensors. 
-Vision based: Use passive optical motion capture technology by setting cameras to capture the dynamic image of a specially designed glove with markers, then use the machine vision technique to process the images and correlate the local variation of image to the motion of fingers or change in the hand gesture [7,8]. The vision based hand tracking system has non-contact perception function, making hand motion detection convenient and efficient. Besides, machine vision and imaging analysis based on camara involve expensive components and complex algorithms [9], which are very expensive for ordinary users.
The main advantage of a vision based system is its high tracking accuracy, but it has drawbacks such as sensitivity to light intensity fluctuations and occlusion issues, which may lead to tracking errors [10].
-Sensors based: The sensor-based systems directly detect the motion and bending of the fingers using various types of sensors such as accelerometers [4], gyroscopes, magnetic sensors, resistive sensors, and ElectroMyoGraphy (EMG) sensors [11] etc. To a certain it can help to mitigate the problem of vision-based system. Besides, the sensor-based systems are also in general more compact and inexpensive. However, acceleration or inertial sensors are generally susceptible to gravitational artifacts due to the rotation and vibration of arms or bodies.
In our research, we intend to design and develop a magnetic sensors based device which is hihgly compact and have ability to detect finger motions real-time accurately. Because magnetic sensors have advantages over limitations of vision based systems which severely restricted the adoption of hand tracking in real-world applications (bulky tethered systems is impractical and line of sight or privacy concerns) [12].
Finger tips are significant marks of hand kinematics analysis, which have fewer amounts than joint angles of fingers and simpler structure. We intend to fix a magnetic sensor on each fingertips and a permanent magnet on the dorsal side of the hand to detect finger motions. Since the magnetic permeability of the human body is very similar to air, water and other non-ferromagnetic materials, it does not affect the static magnetic field [13]. The low-cost, compact, and accessible hand-finger motion tracking system is possible.
1.3 Contributions 
We propose a magnetic hand-finger motion tracking system which is simple, compact, low-cost, accurate and unobstructive for intelligent human-computer interface and various other applications involving hand gestures recognization. The core principle is relative fingertips position estimating with the use of magnetic sensors, then detect the hand gestures from the orientation and locations of the fingertips. The main contributions of our research are:
1.	A intelligent finger motion tracking system using magnetic sensors is porposed. For sensors detecting part of the system, we choose the scheme that measure the orientations and locations of sensors in motion in a stationary magnetic field created by one permanent magnet. A permanent magnet is fixed on the dorsal side of the hand. Five 9-axis IMUs is settled on each of the fingertips, and one 6-axis IMU is fixed with the permanent magnet in order to achieve the attitude calibration and distance measurement between IMUs. After we get the result of finger motion by combining each 9-axis sensors’ orientations and locations (angular velocity on 3-axis, acceleration rate on 3-axis, and magnetic flux density on 3-axis), the next step is to adopt deep learning approaches to realize the real-time gesture recognization function. Various common gestures can be displayed as corresponding patterns when we make actual movements.
2.	A set of algorithms for computing orientations and locations of sensors on the fingertips are proposed. First, we use EKF method for estimating the orientations of the 9-axis sensors on the fingertips to the 6-axis sensors on the dorsal side of the hand. After orthogonalization the coordinate system of two sensors through matrix operation, we apply L-M algorithm to calculate the linear distance between those two sensors to get the locations of 9-axis sensors. The L-M algorithm is based on a dipole model which approximate the magnet as a dipole under the research condition. Our experiments show the dipole model satisfied high approximation and accuracy within a certain range which is sufficient for finger motion tracking and gesture recognization. 
3.	A DNN method is adopted to achieve the real-time gesture recognization function. DNN map the features of existing spatial samples to another feature space through layer by layer feature mapping, in order to learn better feature representation for existing inputs. Firstly we maintain the posture of a specified gesture on the device and create positional data of the gesture in three-dimensional space through the movements and rotations of the hand and wrist. Then we cyclically group and train all data to obtain high accuracy in both training and testing sets. Finally, we use the wearable device to continuously make any gesture in the gesture library, the terminal can accurately display the corresponding gesture pattern.
We develop our device prototype on a SBC: Raspberry pi 4b. It is also fixed on the dorsal side of hand aiming to read data and computing the orientations and locations of sensors. The data from 9-axis sensors are transmitted by I2C bus real-timely to the SBC for the next step of attitude calibration and distance calculation. Besides, we use our originally designed PCB to achieve improvements on stability and integration. Finally we fabricate prototype device on a left-hand glove, improve the compactness and comfort additionally.
CHAPTER 2
THEORETICAL BASICS
In this chapter, the working principle of the accelerometer and gyroscope in the IMU used in this paper is introduced, then the measuring principle of the Hall effect magnetic sensor is described, the physical meaning of the basic data we obtained through the nine axis sensor is analyzed.,then the use of quaternion in helping to improve the efficiency of the rotation algorithm is introduced. Finally the communication flow of I2C protocol is introduced and the calculation of Jacobian matrix.
2.1 IMU Measurement Principle
The IMUs used in this research are MEMS 3-axis gyroscope and 3-axis accelerometer with digital outputs. 
- Gyroscopes:  or gyros, are devices that measure or maintain rotational motion. MEMS gyros are small, inexpensive sensors that measure angular velocity. The units of angular velocity are measured in degrees per second (°/s) or revolutions per second (rps). Angular velocity is simply a measurement of speed of rotation.
The gyro within MEMS is tiny in scale (tipically under 100 micrometers), When the gyro is rotated, a small resonating mass is shifted as the angular velocity changes (Fig. 2.1). This movement is converted into very low-current electrical signals that can be amplified and converted into digital signals by amplifiers and ADC modules.
- Accelerometer:  or accels, are devices that measure acceleration, which is the rate of change of the velocity of an object. They measure in meters per second squared (m/s2) or in G-forces (g). A single G-force for us here on planet Earth is equivalent to 9.8 m/s2, but this does vary slightly with elevation (and will be a different value on different planets due to variations in gravitational pull). Accelerometers are useful for sensing vibrations in systems or for orientation applications.
		Generally, accelerometers contain capacitive plates internally. Some of these are fixed, while others are attached to minuscule springs that move internally as acceleration forces act upon the sensor. As these plates move in relation to each other, the capacitance between them changes. From these changes in capacitance, the acceleration can be determined. Other accelerometers can be centered around piezoelectric materials (Fig. 2.2). These tiny crystal structures output electrical charge when placed under mechanical stress. 'continue'
Okay, please continue.

2.2 Hall-Effect Magnetic Sensor Measurement Principle
	Magnetic sensor (mag) a device that translates the magnitude and fluctuations of magnetic flux into electrical signals. The existing mag technology is usually based on two principles: magnetoresistance effect and Hall-effect. The mag used in this study is composed and integrated of a Hall element compass, which is the most extensively used sensors for sensing magnetic fields. 
	The Lorentz force produces a voltage perpendicular to the direction of the current and magnetic field which is the hall voltage (Fig. 2.3). According to the left hand rule, the direction of the voltage varies with the direction of the magnetic flux. The magnitude and direction of the magnetic field is subsequently possible to be detected by read the magnitude and direction of the voltage .
2.3 Quaternion
Euler rotation, quaternion, and matrix rotation are all mathematical methods for representing the orientation of objects. Compared to the other two methods, the quaternion has smaller storage space, higher computational efficiency, and no deadlock issues. However, it can not represent the orientations intuitively. 
The mathematical expression for quaternion is:
Q ⃗=q_0+q ⃗=q_0+q_1 i ⃗+q_2 j ⃗+q_3 k ⃗
Where q_0 is the is the scalar part, and q ⃗ is the vector part. And i ⃗, j ⃗, and k ⃗ are the unit vectors of the x, y, and z axis respectively.
This is the trigonometric expression for quaternion. θ is the rotation angle around the reference axis ranges in (−π, π).
Since both of Euler rotation, quaternion, and matrix rotation can represent the orientation of a point in specific coordinate system, the mutual transformation of the same rotational motion expressed in different ways will make our calculation of the final position of the object more flexible and convenient. Starting from the three-axis rotational motions in the matrix rotation coordinate system (Fig. 2.4), After derivation and verification, we obtained the transforming expressions between quaternion and Euler rotation written as follow. The rest of transforming expressions for the other two methods can be found in Appendix 2A [14]:
2.4 I2C Communications Protocol
I2C is a two-wire interface comprised of the signals serial data (SDA) and serial clock (SCL). In general, the lines are open-drain and bi-directional. In a generalized I2C interface implementation, attached devices can be a master or a slave. The master device puts the slave address on the bus, and the slave device with the matching address acknowledges the master. 
I2C data bytes are defined to be 8-bits long. Each byte transferred must be followed by an acknowledge (ACK) signal. The clock for the acknowledge signal is generated by the master, while the receiver generates the actual acknowledge signal by pulling down SDA and holding it low during the HIGH portion of the acknowledge clock pulse 
2.5 Jacobian Matrix
	Jacobian matrix is the basis of robotics, aircraft attitude, navigation and other research fields, which is going to be used for linearization in section 4.2. It essentially is a matrix formed by the first order partial derivative in a certain way, and its determinant is called Jacobian determinant. The importance of the Jacobian matrix lies in reflecting the optimal linear approximation of a differentiable equation to a given point, which can linearize a nonlinear equation system at a reference point, such as linear objects required for linear model predictive control in autonomous driving control. 
	For example, Suppose there is a function that maps from an n-dimensional Euclidean space to an m-dimensional Euclidean space, consisting of m real functions:
The partial derivative of these functions (if any) can form a matrix with m rows and n columns (m × n), which is called Jacobian matrix:
CHAPTER 3
DESIGN OF ARCHITECTURE AND HARDWARE STRUCTURE
3.1 Introduction
In this chapter, the design and development of architecture and hardware structure of the intelligent finger motion tracking system is discussed. 
We chose an IMMU-based hand-finger pose estimation device implemented in  ‘Hand-finger pose trackingusing inertial and nagnetic sensors’ [15] for learning and reproduction. The positioning principle and algorithms used in our research are  basically the same. The difference is that the reference system can only support motion detection of two fingers (thumb and index) (Fig. 3.2(a)), while our research supports detection of all postures and movements involved in the entire hand.
A second generation PCB extended board for our SBC is designed and applied in the whole architecture, and with the connections by Qwiic cables between sensors and PCB, the stability and reliability of the device is improved. Since the outputs of our chosen 9-axis IMU and magnetic sensors are digital, we adopt I2C communication method to keep reading data at a high speed.
3.2 Architecture Design
	The overall design architecture of our system is to fix a magnetic sensor on each fingertips and also one magnetic sensor with SBC and permanent magnet on the dorsal side of the hand to detect finger motions (Fig. 3.1). Since the magnetic moment of the  permanent magnet has to be big enough to ensure the effective detecting distance, which resulting to be much heavier than sensor chip, our architecture design can effectively reduce the weight of the equipment and ensuring the atability of components during experiment and  measurement process do not cause systematic errors due to shaking.
